details: Antipyrine is one of the drugs that induce leucocytosis, similar to Ergotin, salicylates, and tuberculin. Acts especially on the vasomotor centers, causing dilation of capillaries of skin and consequent circumscribed patches of hyperaemia and swelling. In large doses causes profuse perspiration, dizziness, cyanosis, and somnolence, albumen and blood in urine. Acute erythema multiform.

Heart: Faintness, with sensation of stoppage of heart
Eyes: Conjunctiva red and oedematous, with lachrymation
Stomach: Nausea and vomiting; burning and pain
Mind: Fear of becoming insane; nervous anxiety; hallucinations of sight and hearing
Head: Headache under ears with earache
Throbbing headache; sensation of constriction
Flashes of heat
Mouth: Ulceration of lips and tongue; vesicles and bullae
Skin: Dark blotches on skin of penis, sometimes with oedema
Urticaria, appearing and disappearing suddenly, with internal coldness

name: Antipyrine
